item.title: By: Yoseph Barash
item.dc:creator: Yoseph Barash
item.description:
This blog + responses is a great resource for anyone thinking about this topic! Thank you all for this.
Two comments:
(1) I have one small concrete suggestion following the recommendation in the blog ("If youâ€™re going to cite a preprint, make it clear that itâ€™s a preprint in the reference list, and in the main text if possible"): Journals should have a visual cue for a citation which is an archived paper. This would help readers be more conscious of claims that are based on those (and therefore may warrant extra caution or looking into) compared to papers that already went through peer review. I agree that a community-based review is the future, but until this happens incorporating such a small fix would go a long way to allow citing archive papers while making readers aware they are exactly that when going through papers.
(2) (This is the ranting part) There is a related issue which has not been discussed here, about how archive papers should be treated during grant review. Sure, your own archive papers can now be cited and that's great for preliminary results (much better than writing "manuscript in preparation"). But what about archive papers that unsupportive grant reviewers bring as "evidence" against your application? Sure, bad peer-reviewed papers can happen just the same, but a grant reviewer would not dare to say (I think?) with the same level of authority "They did not compare to X and X claims their method is bad" if X was a talk they heard. In this case, though, X is an archived paper which simply states such a claim, without a shred of proof. And X can write this in an archived paper, as there is no accountability. Sure, one could use the comment sections and start a fight every time such a claim is posted, but that can become ugly/confrontational very quickly and there is no system in place to protect you as a junior person. I'm not saying I have a clear solution, but I do think people are already abusing the archive system, whether intentionally or not.

item.title: By: Irene Hames
item.dc:creator: Irene Hames
item.description:
Great to see this important post and so many taking part in the discussion. Really pleased to see the importance of citation good practice highlighted and responsibilities outlined. Iâ€™m a firm believer that citation of preprints should become a natural part of scholarly referencing and attribution, and include such citations in my own writing (preprint alone if no journal publication, both journal citation and preprint if preprint goes on to be published in a journal), e.g.
Bik, E. M., Casadevall, A., Fang, F. C. (2016) The prevalence of inappropriate image duplication in biomedical research publications. mBio, 7(3), e00809-16. doi:10.1128/mBio.00809-16. Pre-print published bioRxiv 20 April 2016. doi:10.1101/049452
Many journals wonâ€™t have considered the issue, some may not even be familiar with the concept of preprints, so Iâ€™d encourage anyone who comes across cases where preprint citation isnâ€™t allowed to do what Marc Robinson-Rechavi has done with Nucleic Acids Research and write to the editor/managing editor. It would be very helpful to include links to good discussions on the topic to facilitate editorial board discussions.
If citations are removed by a copyeditor, then definitely write to the editor/managing editor. Copyeditors may be working to old style manuals or a publisherâ€™s standard guidelines and the journal editorial side may not be aware this is happening. During my 20 years as a journal managing editor I used to alert our production editors to new policies arising from our editorial board discussions and then periodically (and whenever there was a change in production editor) check they were being held to.

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/should-we-cite-preprints/#comment-2663">Chris Hartgerink</a>.
Hey Chris,
Yes, you're right about this part actually. So originally, I mis-interpreted the chart to show that ~100% of preprints in HEP go on to be published in journals - that would have been a stronger argument! But I edited it after noticing the mistake, and for some reason left it in rather than deleting altogether. In fact, are there any data on the proportion of preprints that eventually get published? That would actually be useful.. Looking into why things remain unpublished would also be sweet, although someone has to have worked on this before, right..?
Jon
